Speech-to-Handwriting Robot Using Dobot Magician

Abstract

In an era dominated by digital communication, handwriting retains its emotional and functional significance—especially in education, personalization, and accessibility. This project presents an innovative speech-to-text handwriting system that bridges natural human communication (speech) and robotic actuation (handwriting) using the Dobot Magician robotic arm. The system is designed to convert spoken words into handwritten text in real time without any physical interaction, offering valuable support for individuals with limited motor function. At the heart of the project lies the fusion of mathematics and robotics. Speech recognition is powered by a lightweight offline STT engine (Vosk), which processes audio input and outputs text. This text is then dynamically translated into smooth vector paths using mathematical representations of letterforms and coordinated motion planning. These vectors guide the Dobot Magician’s end-effector using precise inverse kinematics and trajectory control, ensuring legible and fluid handwriting. The result is a touch-free, intuitive pipeline from voice to ink that serves educational, assistive, and industrial purposes. This project not only showcases applied linear algebra, geometry, and control theory but also highlights the power of robotics to make communication more accessible and expressive
